text:
May I suggest the following clarifications for the mod_autoindex documentation (I could provide patches if you like):

1) For all AddIcon* directives:
The URL does not have to be a relative URL, it can also be an absolute which makes sense if it's on external server.

2) It should be mentioned that a ^^BLANKICON^^ is only required (and suggested) if one doesn't us HTMLTable.

3) It should be suggested to add ".ht*" to IndexIgnore. Although these files wouldn't be displayed (if access was denied because of "-ShowForbidden" each listing would cause errors like:
"client denied by server configuration: /var/www/.htaccess"
creator: calestyo@scientia.net
calestyo@scientia.net
text:
4) At http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_autoindex.html#indexorderdefault
"You can force a directory listing to only be displayed in a particular order by combining this directive with the SuppressColumnSorting index option; this will prevent the client from requesting the directory listing in a different order."
... seems to be outdated information, as SuppressColumnSorting contains only whether the headers are links or not nowadays.
That must be replaced with IgnoreClient option IMHO

5) The following directives should list their defaults:
IndexIgnore: "."
IndexOptions: is there any default?
creator: calestyo@scientia.net
rbowen@apache.org
text:
> 1) For all AddIcon* directives:
> The URL does not have to be a relative URL, it can also be an absolute which
> makes sense if it's on external server.

Done, r1059559

> 2) It should be mentioned that a ^^BLANKICON^^ is only required (and suggested)
> if one doesn't us HTMLTable.


I've added a note to this effect in r1059561 although I haven't made it quite as strong as you infer. BLANKICON isn't needed if you're using HTMLTable, but it certainly doesn't hurt anything to have it. It's simply not used.
creator: rbowen@apache.org

text:
> 3) It should be suggested to add ".ht*" to IndexIgnore. Although these files
> wouldn't be displayed (if access was denied because of "-ShowForbidden" each
> listing would cause errors like:
> "client denied by server configuration: /var/www/.htaccess"

The default configuration file contains:

IndexIgnore .??* *~ *# HEADER* README* RCS CVS *,v *,t

That first one - .??* - covers .ht* and many other files that one would like to hide.

Every third-party distro that I've looked at also includes something like this in the default. Also, the example in the docs included .htaccess.

However, what I've done in r1059562 is make the example given in the docs match the example in the default config file provided at conf/extra/httpd-autoindex.conf, which is as shown above.
creator: rbowen@apache.org

text:
(In reply to comment #1)
> 4) At http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_autoindex.html#indexorderdefault
> "You can force a directory listing to only be displayed in a particular order
> by combining this directive with the SuppressColumnSorting index option; this
> will prevent the client from requesting the directory listing in a different
> order."
> ... seems to be outdated information, as SuppressColumnSorting contains only
> whether the headers are links or not nowadays.
> That must be replaced with IgnoreClient option IMHO

Sort of. Ignoring the client's preferences is a two-part thing. You must SuppressColumnSorting to remove the sort link at the top of the column, and also IgnoreClient to prevent them just putting the sort arguments directly in the query string.

However, I think that this paragraph is just phrased wrong. This directive is for setting a *default* sort order. The decision to not let the client reorder is a separate thing, and we shouldn't imply that it's necessary in order to set a default ordering. Will rephrase accordingly.
creator: rbowen@apache.org

text:
Hi Rich.

Thanks for all the changes,... looked them up and I'm quite happy with them, except perhaps the
IndexIgnore .??*

IMHO the default example (and also the docs) should be changed from ".??*" to ".ht*", whit the reason, that there is (IMO) not reason to ignore/prohibit more than necessary.
".??*" would ignore/prohibit all dot-files having at least two characters... why should we do this?

(reopening therefore, if you do not agree,.. simply close it :) )

Cheers,
Chris.

creator: DRuggeri@primary.net
text:
In the UNIX world, files beginning with a dot are what would be considered "hidden" files a la the Windows world. I would contend that the example ought to exclude any file beginning with a dot - however many characters long the file is.

IMO, I think that is the intention of this particular example.

creator: rbowen@apache.org
text: Yes, I agree with Daniel's assessment here, and believe that we should continue to hide, and recommend hiding, all "dot files". It is what people have come to expect, and it's a convention for hiding files in the Unix world, as Daniel says.
